text.p: The international body supervising Bosnia's post-war elections said on Sunday it had certified the results of national balloting on September 14.

Kasim Begic, the Bosnian member of the Provisional Election Commission of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), told reporters: "The preliminary results are certified as final."
The decision brought to an end days of dispute over allegations that more votes had been cast than there were voters.

Bosnia's first poll since fighting ended last November selected a three-member collective presidency, a national House of Representatives, separate Moslem-Croat and Serb parliaments, a Serb republic president and cantonal assemblies.
The certification of election results is expected to pave the way for the permanent lifting of economic sanctions against rump Yugoslavia, comprising Serbia and Montenegro, diplomats said.
The sanctions, which were suspended last November, were imposed by the U.N. Security Council for Belgrade's military support of separatist Bosnian Serb forces.
